**Summer Hiking: 5 hiking trails for active weekends**

From the green landscapes of the Bahamas to the red desert of Turkey, we have collected the most scenic and fascinating hiking trails that can be explored this summer.

![Image](morneblanc.png)

**The top of the Morn Blanc in the Seychelles. Cappadocia, Turkey**

Cappadocia is located in the central part of Turkey and is a semi-desert region of the country. Among tourists, Cappadocia is known for its unique landscapes and abundance of historical sights. Hiking here easily adapts to the possibilities of tourists, as guides willingly offer trails of varying difficulty levels. Some of the most popular routes are through the valleys of Dove and Love, the Red Valley and the Valley of the Roses, as well as the route through the valley of the Earth, where there are rock churches.

![Image](tyrkey.png)

**Stanage Edge Rock District in UK**

One of the most beautiful walking routes in England, which is ten and a half kilometers long, begins and ends in the picturesque village of Hatersage. In general, Stanage Edge is a popular place among British mountaineers, and you will understand why when you reach the edge of Stanage Edge on a green trail.

![Image](edge.png)

**Andros - Bahamas coastline with palm trees.**

For a full experience in the Bahamas you do not need to limit yourself to exploring the depths. Be sure to go to Blue Holes National Park, where in addition to the blue holes and running streams you can get acquainted with 20 species of wild orchids and 120 species of birds. In the jungle of the park is easy to get lost, so hire a guide and don't forget your comfortable shoes.

![Image](bagam.jpeg)

**Morne Blanc Trail, Seychelles - Morn Blanc Peak**

The reality is that to the Morn Blanc Peak, which offers a sentimental view, there is a one-and-a-half kilometer winding road, during which you can meet fog and certainly climb through the mountainous terrain through tea plantations. It is said to be worth it. After all, the view from the peak opens up to the whole island and neighboring areas. It is better to go on the road in the morning to avoid fog and sun.

![Image](morne.png)

** Valley of Whales, Egypt - Wadi Al-Hitan**

The Valley of Whales in Egypt, known as Wadi Al-Hitan in Arabic, is a place where you can track the evolution of the whale from a land animal to an ocean mammal. The valley is included in the UNESCO World Heritage List and is a popular place for tourists who are eager for active recreation. Smooth landscapes make the Valley of Whales accessible for beginner hikers, and you can also come here for camping, kayaking, horseback riding and stargazing - from the desert they look especially spectacular.

![Image](egipet.jpeg)
